urn:contentItem:5PTH-YVX1-JD34-V1NB-00000-00Beaufort planned burn postponed2017-10-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisBeaufort planned burn postponed

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority have postponed a planned burn around Camp Hill Road at Beaufort.

Firefighters had scheduled the planned burn's ignition for Tuesday but postponed the operation due to unsuitable forecast weather conditions in the coming days.

Forest Fire Management Victoria has said it will be continue to monitor the weather and fuel conditions to look for future opportunities to delivery this burn.

"There is a potential for later this week, however standard notifications will be issued to advise when it is scheduled, a Forest Fire Management Victoria statement said.

The burn was originally planned to last for four days.

When the planned burn does take place, smoke might be visible from nearby localities and communities, which could also be affected by smoke from this planned burn.

Forest Fire Management Victoria has advised:

Smoke

Roads

Access to forest or park recreation sites

For parks closures, please refer to Parks Victoria on 13 1963 or visit http://parkweb.vic.gov.au/

Stay informed about Planned Burning online at http://ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn

Call the VicEmergency Hotline on freecall 1800 226 226

Visit VicEmergency website www.emergency.vic.gov.au

Sign up for automated notifications about planned burns near you via www.ffm.vic.gov.au/pbns

Callers who are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment can contact via the National Relay Service on 1800 555 677.

urn:contentItem:5DKR-6V81-JD6G-442M-00000-00Campfire flares up in forest: fire safety2014-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexis2014Campfire flares up in forest: fire safety

Campers have been reminded to extinguish campfires properly before leaving the region's state forests, after an abandoned campfire ignited a larger fire on Wednesday in East Boyd State Forest south of Eden.

Forestry Corporation of NSW's protection supervisor Julian Armstrong said the fire was extinguished quickly by Forestry Corporation fire fighters after it was reported by South East Fibre Exports staff, who discovered the fire and undertook the initial attack.

'Local state forests are popular spots to visit as the weather heats up because you can pitch a tent anywhere for free and enjoy our large network of mountain bike, trail bike and four-wheel drive tracks,' Mr Armstrong said.

'As the weather heats up and the forests dry out, we're reminding campers to take extreme care when lighting and extinguishing campfires.

'Campers should use established campfires wherever possible, clear leaves and grass at least two metres from the fire and thoroughly douse the fire with water before leaving to ensure it is fully extinguished.

'As the weather heats up, there will also be periods when fires are banned completely, so visitors should check the fire regulations with the Rural Fire Service before heading into the forest and pay attention to any signs in the forest.

'Forestry Corporation takes fire management seriously and we invest heavily in training our fire fighting staff and upgrading our equipment and roads so that we can rapidly detect fires and quickly respond and get them under control.

'While we were able to quickly extinguish yesterday's fire, as we move further into the fire danger period we do urge visitors to help us protect the region's forests by taking extreme care when using campfires.'

urn:contentItem:5SND-TC71-F0J6-J485-00000-00Traditional burn to re-ignite traditional practices2018-06-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisTraditional burn to re-ignite traditional practices

FOREST Fire Management Victoria is working with Wotjobaluk Traditional Owners to reinforce cultural land management practices across the Wimmera and reduce bushfire risk to communities.

Weather permitting, a Wotjobaluk traditional burn at the Centenary Park Camping and Picnic Area inside the Mt Arapiles-Tooan State Park was set to be undertaken on Thursday, June 28.

Aboriginal planned burns are typically cooler, slower burns where fire is lit in patches to allow the flames to take their natural paths.

These types of burns are becoming entrenched in the Wimmera Fire District's planned burning program.

Working in partnership with Forest Fire Management Victoria, Wotjobaluk Traditional Owners have been planning this burn for some months now, as a continuation of last years' re-introduction of ancient Aboriginal fire practices into the landscape.

Wotjobaluk Traditional Owner and Parks Victoria ranger Damien Skurrie said he was passionate about this opportunity to continue Aboriginal burning in the Mt Arapiles-Tooan landscape.

"I'm so proud to rekindle this once forgotten practice on my country and know that my ancestors are looking down and observing what we are doing," he said.

"Being able to practice my culture is important because it's how we connect to or identify with this country as Aboriginal people; it is important that we continue on with this practice for the generations to come."

Barengi Gadjin chief executive officer Michael Stewart said he supported the return of traditional burning in this partnership approach.

"Fire has been an integral part of how Wotjobaluk peoples have successfully managed the land for thousands of years," he said.

"To have our members be part of putting fire back into the landscape to help heal Country is a wonderful event for culture and history.

"This burn is critical to the restoration of Country; fire is about health of Country and of People. Seeing smoke rising from traditional burns is a powerful and healing sign for everyone."

Forest Fire Management Victoria Wimmera District Manager Glenn Rudolph said the re-ignition of last year's Walpa Dyurrita cultural burn would be a significant day.

"We are fortunate that we have several Wotjobaluk people within our Forest Fire Management Victoria crews who have extensive experience in contemporary fire management, and can combine current and traditional fire knowledge to better inform our burning practices," he said.

The burn is expected to be ignited on Thursday, June 28.

Residents and motorists along Western Highway between Garoke and Horsham may see or smell smoke associated with this planned burn.

urn:contentItem:5RMM-0B71-F0JP-W0J7-00000-00Fast track to success2018-02-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Fast track to successLaura Armitage

KEEN mountain bikers can navigate a new track in the Yarra State Forest opened by the State Government.

Forest Fire Management and the Yarra Ranges Mountain Bikers worked together to prepare the Wesburn track, named Hey Hey My My, which opened to the community on January 24.

Last year, the Warburton-based Yarra Ranges Mountain Bikers received a $1000 Leader Local Grant to buy tools and protection equipment to maintain the track.

Forest Fire Management district manager Nigel Brennan said the track was a community win.

"Forest Fire Management Victoria is continuing to work closely with the group and has established a safety and maintenance schedule for the year," Mr Brennan said."This is a really good example of how we can work with local community groups to provide activities in the area that people want." Yarra Ranges Mountain Bikers president Doug Greenall said the track was graded to international standards. "The steep climb contains 35 switchback corners with loose rocky off camber sections," Mr Greenall said.

"The descent is a fast and flowy single track with features including jumps, drops, rock gardens, tight corners and steep sections."For more details on activities in the Yarra State Fores, check out the More to Explore app or phone 5965 9901.

urn:contentItem:5XT6-T8D1-F0J6-J3D3-00000-00More than 1000 hectares of land torched as fires continue to burn2019-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisMore than 1000 hectares of land torched as fires continue to burnJessica Howard

More than 1000 hectares of land is believed to have been torched in bushfires across the south-west this weekend, with six fires still out-of-control.

Heywood incident controller Mark Mellington said Friday had "fairly nasty weather conditions followed by a significant lightening event in the evening".

"We had a number of fires start on Friday night as a result of that lightening," he said.

"Majority of the fires occurred throughout the south-western part of Victoria, including west of Casterton, around the Dartmoor and Digby areas, and further west in the Cobboboonee Forest.

"We currently have six fires that are out-of-control, at least five that are contained and another few that are at a lower status that we're fairly comfortable with."

Mr Mellington said he believed more than 1000 hectares had been burnt over the weekend.

"I think that number will grow significantly today. A couple of fires are on the move," he said

"Every available resource has been called for. We've used a range of aircraft for fire bombing as well as aerial observation to try and help us to understand the extent of the fires.

"We've also had a significant number of bulldozers and excavators and other heavy machinery to help with the construction of fire lines, as well as a number of trucks and water carrying freights from both CFA and Forest Fire Management."

No lives or properties have been reported lost.

Mr Mellington said it had been a long weekend for firefighters.

"A lot of our firefighters have already had several rotations through to either Gippsland or interstate," he said.

"In terms of how people are travelling, we're at the stage that we would ordinarily be at much later in the season."

Forest Fire Management Victoria issued a watch and act message for Hotspur at 3.02pm on Sunday.

There is a bushfire 19 kilometres east of Dartmoor that is not yet under control. The watch and act message replaced an earlier advice message issued at 12.25pm.

Firefighters have been unable to stop the fire and it has now crossed Big Hill road and is moving towards the Dartmoor-Hamilton Road.

Forest Fire Management Victoria has urged people not to wait.

"Leaving now is the safest option," the message said.

"Conditions may change and get worse very quickly. Emergency Services may not be able to help you if you decide to stay."

There are also advice messages for Casterton, Corndale, Lake Mundi, Lindsay, Tullich.

A bushfire at 19 kilometres west Of Casterton is not yet under control. The bushfire is travelling from Tullich Road in Nangeela State Forest in a northerly direction.

Fires at Millard Track, Lake Condah; Digby-Strathdownie Road, Killara and Wrights Swamp Road in the Cobboboonee Forest are also out-of-control.

Mr Mellington said people will see smoke during the day and potentially a fire flow at night.

"People in nearby communities need to stay informed. The Vic Emergency app is a good tool for that," he said.

"There will be road and track closures, there already is in place around the areas. Some of that information is accessible on vicroads.vic.gov.au.

"And very importantly, people should review their fire plan if they don't already have one. You can find details about fire plans on the CFA website."

urn:contentItem:5PP6-6731-JD34-V3VM-00000-00Planned burn put on hold2017-10-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisPlanned burn put on hold

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority have postponed a four day planned burn around Camp Hill Road at Beaufort.

Firefighters had scheduled the burn's ignition for Tuesday but postponed the operation due to unsuitable forecast weather conditions in the coming days.

Forest Fire Management Victoria has said it will be continue to monitor the weather and fuel conditions to look for future opportunities.

"There is a potential for later this week, however standard notifications will be issued to advise when it is scheduled," a Forest Fire Management Victoria statement said.

When the planned burn does take place, smoke might be visible from nearby localities and communities, which could also be affected by smoke from this planned burn.

Forest Fire Management Victoria has advised to close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering your home.

If you experience any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024.

Furthermore, road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke and road signs may be in place to slow traffic.

It is advised drivers obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the burn.

Be aware of planned burns happening in your local area and stay clear of areas where burns are taking place or areas that have recently been burnt.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted and for parks closures, please refer to Parks Victoria on 13 1963 or visit www.parkweb.vic.gov.au.

Stay informed about Planned Burning online at www.fm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn, call the VicEmergency Hotline 1800 226 226 or visit VicEmergency website at   www.emergency.vic.gov.au.

You can also sign up for automated notifications about planned burns via www.ffm.vic.gov.au/pbns.

urn:contentItem:4PGH-W570-TX52-F133-00000-00Ukrainian President pitches in to fight forest fire2007-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 9

Reuters

Ukrainian President pitches in to fight forest fire

KIEV: Ukrainian President Viktor Yushchenko diverted his plane to join crews battling a forest fire that has been raging for three days and demanded the resignation of the minister responsible for public safety.

Mr Yushchenko, gearing up for a parliamentary election next month, picked up a shovel on Tuesday, heaved sand on to smouldering woodland and strained to help firefighters push a vehicle out of a bog.

The President, long at odds with a government led by his archrival, Prime Minister Viktor Yanukovich, was returning to Kiev from southern Ukraine when he spotted a long plume of smoke. He ordered the pilot to change course and land.

A statement from the President's office said Mr Yushchenko had ''personally taken control of firefighting and rescue efforts'' and accused Emergencies Minister Nestor Shufrych of misleading the public on efforts to bring the fire under control. ''The minister has displayed total incompetence and is completely uninformed,'' presidential chief of staff Viktor Baloga said.

''The President demands that the Prime Minister review whether Mr Shufrych should remain in his job. Incompetent and unprofessional individuals have no place in government.''

Officials said more than 600 people, including residents, were still battling the blaze in the Kherson region last night.

The President has been critical of the Government's handling of a series of emergencies, including the derailment last month of a train carrying phosphorus, which sparked a fire and prompted the evacuation of hundreds of people.

Mr Yushchenko beat Mr Yanukovich in the rerun of a rigged 2004 election after weeks of ''Orange Revolution'' rallies, but Mr Yanukovich made a comeback and became Prime Minister last year.

A long struggle for power prompted the President to dissolve parliament and call a new election. Polls show the contest is unlikely to produce much change, with Mr Yanukovich's Regions Party leading but allies of the President close behind.

urn:contentItem:568M-J381-JD3N-52PS-00000-00Crime adds to forest fire fears2012-08-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisPg. 4Crime adds to forest fire fears

A FOREST at Logan Village could become an inferno this summer and threaten lives and property if criminals continue to torch stolen vehicles in the area.

Jimboomba Police Senior Sergeant Bill Sheehan said the Hancock Pine Forest was a known hot spot for criminals. More than half of all the stolen cars from the area were dumped in the forest and torched.

Snr-Sgt Sheehan said unregistered cars were also dumped in the forest, as were by-products of drug labs, stolen boats and other stolen property.

And only last Friday dozens of armed police were deployed to the forest after a car believed to contain stolen property from armed robberies was found by pig shooters.

Snr-Sgt Sheehan said the forest had been the scene of a lot of illegal activity during the past couple of years.

``There is a real concern though with the arson of the vehicles,'' he said.

``Our concern is that once the terrain dries out and becomes more brittle because to dry conditions it will lead to bush fires.''

Snr-Sgt Sheehan said there was a joint program with Lend Lease, the developer of Yarrabilba, the fire service and police to maintain fire breaks and conduct regular patrols.

He said the biggest concern was that if the fire got out of control it could threaten property and people.

urn:contentItem:5X1F-Y551-JD34-V0S0-00000-00First burnoff of the spring2019-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8First burnoff of the springGreg Gliddon

PERFECT spring conditions on Wednesday have given Forest Fire Management Victoria crews a chance to kick off its burn off season with a 3.72 hectare site near Mount Buninyong the first to be set alight.

Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) said it is deep into its preparations for the upcoming bushfire season with fuel burn offs expected to be held right across the district in the coming weeks to prepare for the warmer months.

FFMVic District Manager Jasmine Filmer said planned burns throughout the season will also be held at Blackwood, Daylesford, Beaufort, Snake Valley, Smythesdale and within the Wombat, Lerderderg and Enfield parks and state forests.

"Reducing bushfire fuel means that when they occur, bushfires will be less intense, making it more likely that firefighters can contain them before they spread and impact on people, property and the environment," Ms Filmer said

"We take a whole-of-system approach to fuel reduction that builds on our management of threatened and vulnerable species, involving the development of ecological models and measures of ecosystem resilience under different fire regimes.

"We carry out fuel reduction through planned burning, slashing, mulching and mowing works, and creating and maintaining strategic fuel breaks. These techniques are applied under specific environmental conditions to achieve the desired outcome."

Ms Filmer said there was only a small window each year in order to conduct such burns.

"We understand it is concerning for people to see smoke soon after an active bushfire period," she said.

"If conditions become dry and stay cool across the midlands district, we expect some opportunities to undertake planned burning to become available within the next few weeks.

"There are very limited opportunities where conditions are suitable to undertake these important burns, so it is vital that we take advantage of every opportunity to complete them.

"These opportunities may occur during the school holidays, public holidays and over weekends."

For information to where planned burns are go to ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn

urn:contentItem:5X29-7FN1-JD3N-502Y-00000-00Queensland calls on our forest firefighters2019-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 18Queensland calls on our forest firefightersOLIVIA REED

QUEENSCLIFF and Anglesea Forest Fire Management staff have been deployed to Queensland to provide emergency management support during the bushfires raging across the state.

Specialist personnel from Forest Fire Management Victoria's Colac, Anglesea and Queenscliff are among a multi-agency contingent requested by the Queensland Government.

Fires continue to rage across Queensland, but in the past few days hundreds of people who were forced to flee their homes across southern and southeast Queensland have been allowed to return.

Residents from Peregian Beach, on the Sunshine Coast, were some of the most severely impacted, with police saying a blaze that tore through the area may have been deliberately lit by a teenage boy and girl.

Anglesea's Ellen Harper will use her skills as a logistics officer to co-ordinate a range of areas including meals, accommodation and equipment.

Ms Harper has led and supported logistics during a number of major fires including last year's bushfires in Queensland, the Wye River bushfires and Black Saturday blazes.

Queenscliff's Andrew McKinnon will take on the role of a situation officer tasked with analysing the weather, fire movement and other data to produce reports on the fire situation.

Mr McKinnon has experience assisting with a range of emergencies at a local and state level.

Colac's Sandra Robinson will use her aircraft officer skills as she oversees the management of an air base, and manages a large, varied fleet of aircraft in the firefight. Ms Robinson has more than 20 years' experience in aircraft management and played a key role in the aircraft team during the Wye River bushfires.

The personnel, who flew out of Melbourne Airport last night, will be based in Cairns.

Otway district manager David Roberts was confident they would provide valuable skills and support."These are some of our reg-ion's most experienced emergency management personnel, with years of experience in helping respond to fires and other emergencies," he said.

urn:contentItem:5XFV-39B1-JD34-V32X-00000-00Expect to see smoke near the Kingower State Forest next week2019-11-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisSATURDAYExpect to see smoke near the Kingower State Forest next week

SMOKE might be visible near Kingower next week, with a fuel reduction burn planned in the Kingower State Forest.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA are planning to burn 42 hectares near Mackenzies Gully Road, about one kilometre south west of Kingower.

The burn is expected to be completed between 10am on Monday and 8pm on Friday, November 15.

Smoke might be visible from Kingower, Rheola and Brenanah until Sunday, November 17.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA have provided the following advice:

What to do about:

SMOKE

If you are experiencing any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health and Human Services advises that you should seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024

Close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering

ROADS

Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke

Signs may be in place to slow traffic. Obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire agency crews near the burn

For travel times and roadworks check http://traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au

ACCESS TO FOREST/PARK RECREATION SITES

Be aware of planned burns happening in your local area and stay clear of areas where burns are taking place or areas that have recently been burnt

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted

For parks closures, please refer to Parks Victoria on 13 1963 or visit http://parkweb.vic.gov.au/

Stay informed about Planned Burning

Visit ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn Sign up for automated notifications about planned burns near you at plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au Callers who are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment can contact via the National Relay Service on 1800 555 677. You can register below and make sure you are up to date with everything that's happening in central Victoria.

urn:contentItem:4P7G-YGB0-TXN5-R37D-00000-00RAIN HELPS CHINESE CONTROL FOREST FIRE1987-05-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 12RAIN HELPS CHINESE CONTROL FOREST FIRESource: Reuter

PEKING, Tuesday: China's biggest forest fire for nearly 40 years has been brought under control by rain and the efforts of tens of thousands of people, the People's Daily reported today.

It said that up to 10 mm of man-made and natural rain fell on Sunday and yesterday over the area in the north-east where the blaze has been raging for three weeks.

Firefighters have created rain by firing artillery shells to seed clouds with rain-making chemicals.

"Thanks to the heroic fire-fighting efforts of specialised People's Liberation Army units and the masses, the fire in both the eastern and western sectors has basically been brought under control," the newspaper's overseas edition said.

The fire has killed more than 200 people and destroyed the homes of 50,000 since May 6 in Heilongjiang Province, China's major timber-producing area. The blaze there has destroyed forests estimated to be worth more than 400 million yuan ($A153.62 million).

The paper said an extra 5,000 firefighters had been sent to combat the western wing of the blaze, where flames had threatened vast virgin forests in the neighbouring region of Inner Mongolia.

The New China News Agency said the fire front in the west had been shortened by 50 kilometres after a 15-hour battle by 30,000 people, although two blazes 30 kilometres in length continued to burn near the village of Mohe

The agency said low temperatures and light rain had also slowed the advance of a forest fire in the Baikal area of Soviet Siberia that was now eight kilometres from the border with Inner Mongolia.

urn:contentItem:5DKR-6V81-JD6G-445P-00000-00Campfire flares up in forest: fire safety2014-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisEDITORS-PICKSCampfire flares up in forest: fire safetyStan Gorton

CAMPERS have been reminded to extinguish campfires properly before leaving the region's State forests, after an abandoned campfire ignited a larger fire on Wednesday in East Boyd State Forest south of Eden.

Forestry Corporation of NSW's protection supervisor Julian Armstrong said the fire was extinguished quickly by Forestry Corporation fire fighters after it was reported by South East Fibre Exports staff, who discovered the fire and undertook the initial attack.

'Local State forests are popular spots to visit as the weather heats up because you can pitch a tent anywhere for free and enjoy our large network of mountain bike, trail bike and four-wheel drive tracks,' Mr Armstrong said.

'As the weather heats up and the forests dry out, we're reminding campers to take extreme care when lighting and extinguishing campfires.

'Campers should use established campfires wherever possible, clear leaves and grass at least two metres from the fire and thoroughly douse the fire with water before leaving to ensure it is fully extinguished.

'As the weather heats up, there will also be periods when fires are banned completely, so visitors should check the fire regulations with the Rural Fire Service before heading into the forest and pay attention to any signs in the forest.

'Forestry Corporation takes fire management seriously and we invest heavily in training our fire fighting staff and upgrading our equipment and roads so that we can rapidly detect fires and quickly respond and get them under control.

'While we were able to quickly extinguish yesterday's fire, as we move further into the fire danger period we do urge visitors to help us protect the region's forests by taking extreme care when using campfires.'

Campfire tips:

For more information about Forestry Corporation of NSW, visit www.forestrycorporation.com.au

urn:contentItem:5W0N-YP11-JD34-V143-00000-00Fire Restrictions lifted2019-04-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisFire Restrictions lifted

The Fire Danger Period and Seasonal Prohibited Period will end at 1am on Wednesday, May 1 in all Gippsland municipalities.

CFA's Assistant Chief Officer, Trevor Owen said: "We've had a long and exceptionally dry summer again this year and although the weather is starting to cool down a little, people still need to be extra cautious with fire."

"If you're planning a burn, no matter how small, you must first check your local council's laws about when and where you can burn off and register your burn-off on the Burn Off Notification Line on 1800 668 511, even if it's only a heap of garden rubbish."

"Any fire left unattended in windy conditions can spread into bushland, onto a neighbour's property or into other materials which could cause untold damage," Mr Owen said.

"Our firefighters in Forest Fire Management and CFA have been fighting fires for many months and are now working hard on the planned burning program to protect our communities."

"They do not want to be called out to fires that have started through irresponsible or lazy behaviour."

Always remember to:

Check local by-laws before burning-off and never leave a burn-off unattended

Tell your neighbours and call the Burn Off Notification Line so that brigades don't get called out unnecessarily

Check the weather forecast before you burn off and never burn off in dry, hot, windy conditions

Have enough water to extinguish a possible outbreak - either a hose or at least 10 litres of water

Create a three-metre clearance of all flammable material around your whole burn-off site

Make sure there are enough people to monitor, contain and extinguish your burn safely and effectively. Ensure your burn is 100 per cent out before you leave it.

Forest Fire Management Victoria's Assistant Chief Fire Officer for Gippsland, Beth Roberts said: "People enjoying Gippsland's National Parks and State forests should be as careful with the use of campfires over this period as they were in the Fire Danger Period - we've had too many bushfires caused by campfires this season.

"Anyone living in or travelling through Gippsland needs to keep an eye on the weather and be aware of their surroundings. We've all had a busy fire season this year and we don't want more started through irresponsible behaviour," Dr Roberts said.

"If you are in any doubt about the use of fire on private or public land, the best thing you can do is seek advice from either CFA or Forest Fire Management Victoria."

Information about fire restrictions is available in CFA's 'Can I or Can't I' brochure available at www.cfa.vic.gov.au/restrictions or by phoning the Emergency Vic Hotline on 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:5XT6-T8D1-F0J6-J3BY-00000-00CFA crews control small fires at Brim, Drung2019-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisCFA crews control small fires at Brim, DrungAlexander Darling

Update 5pm: Country Fire Authority crews have controlled a small grass and stubble fire near Brim.

A state control centre spokesman said three trucks had made the scene safe, after the fire was first reported at 4.09am.

Earlier on Sunday afternoone, CFA crews extinguished a small crop fire near the Western Highway at Drung and controlled a header and crop fire at Callawadda, north of Stawell.

Advice warnings to residents surrounding Little Desert and Grampians national parks, where three fires continue to burn out of control, remain current.

Update 1.53pm: Forest Fire Management Victoria workers have closed Mount William Road, as firefighters and aircraft tackle a small bushfire in the Grampians National Park.

In a message to Makefing, Bellfield and Pomonal residents released at 1.05pm, the organisation said the fire was situated south of Mt William Road and burning in a northerly direction.

It said the fire did not represent a threat to surrounding communities.

A state control centre spokesman said crews were first alerted to the fire at 9.59am, that it had burned through three hectares and three trucks were working to control it.

He said another vehicle was working to control a small fire at Mt Lang in the Grampians, near Mirranatwa, that flared up before 12.33pm.

11.53am: Forest Fire Management Victoria has sent firefighters and bulldozers into Little Desert National Park, where a bushfire continues to burn out of control.

A state control centre spokesman said eight vehicles were combating the fire nine kilometres north of Goroke, which started just before midnight on Saturday and had burned through 1041 hectares.

In a message released at 9.31am on Sunday, the authority advised Goroke, Lawloit, Little Desert and Peronne residents to keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.

It said the fire did not represent a threat to any of the four communities. An update is expected by 2.40pm.

The fire danger rating in the Wimmera on each of Sunday, Monday and Tuesday is High.

A further eight vehicles contained a 129-hectare fire in an expanse of Mount Arapiles-Tooan State Park at Clear Lake at 1.50 on Sunday morning.

Five vehicles have contained a 90-hectare fire in bush off W Dixons Road, 10 kilometres northeast of Edenhope.

urn:contentItem:484J-31B0-00VK-22RC-00000-00<published>2003-03-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:25:45Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Domestic News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>WA: Vulnerable mammals killed in WA's biggest forest fire.</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Karen Valenti</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>PERTH, March 13</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">It could be decades before vulnerable, Western Australian mammals are able to re-populate because of the state's biggest forest fire.</p><p nitf:lede="true">More than 100 firefighters are struggling to contain the blaze near Walpole, 422 km south of Perth.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Department of Conservation and Land Management (CALM) expects 35,000 hectares to be blackened before the fire is extinguished.</p><p>CALM's Regional Services Director, Alan Walker, said the blaze was the biggest forest fire in WA for more than 30 years.</p><p>He hoped the fire would be contained by tomorrow, but said the area would not be safe for about a fortnight.</p><p>"There's still a very big job in mopping up, before the area can be declared safe," Mr Walker said.</p><p>Mr Walker said losing the estimated 35,000 hectares of vegetation was a concern, but he was more worried about the devastating effect the blaze was having on native animals.</p><p>He said kangaroos and emus had the means to escape, but there was little hope for smaller mammals such as the chuditch - a small cat-like animal, also known as a quoll in other parts of Australia.</p><p>"With fires of this intensity what happens is you don't get any unburnt pockets," Mr Walker said.</p><p>"So every little nook and cranny is consumed by the fire and that means the process for recolonisation for smaller animals could take many years and perhaps even decades."</p><p>He said among the animals least likely to escape the intense fire were numbats, bandicoots, black-gloved wallabies, mainland quokkas and the chuditch.</p><p>The chuditch had only just been taken off the endangered list and was categorised as a vulnerable species.</p><p>Mr Walker said the intense fire would have also destroyed the creatures' habitats.</p><p>"They need dense thickets of vegetation and it will probably be several years before dense thickets reform," he said.</p><p>At its worst, flame heights reached 40 metres and embers caused spotfires up to three km ahead of the main fire.</p><p>Milder conditions today have eased the fire's intensity.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2003</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:484J-31B0-00VK-22RC-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-28</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="332"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2003 AAP Information Services Pty. In a message to Makefing, Bellfield and Pomonal residents released at 1.05pm, the organisation said the fire was situated south of Mt William Road and burning in a northerly direction.

It said the fire did not represent a threat to surrounding communities.

A state control centre spokesman said crews were first alerted to the fire at 9.59am, that it had burned through three hectares and three trucks were working to control it.

He said another vehicle was working to control a small fire at Mt Lang in the Grampians, near Mirranatwa, that flared up before 12.33pm.

11.53am: Forest Fire Management Victoria has sent firefighters and bulldozers into Little Desert National Park, where a bushfire continues to burn out of control.

A state control centre spokesman said eight vehicles were combating the fire nine kilometres north of Goroke, which started just before midnight on Saturday and had burned through 1041 hectares.

In a message released at 9.31am on Sunday, the authority advised Goroke, Lawloit, Little Desert and Peronne residents to keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond.

It said the fire did not represent a threat to any of the four communities. An update is expected by 2.40pm.

The fire danger rating in the Wimmera on each of Sunday, Monday and Tuesday is High.

A further eight vehicles contained a 129-hectare fire in an expanse of Mount Arapiles-Tooan State Park at Clear Lake at 1.50 on Sunday morning.

Five vehicles have contained a 90-hectare fire in bush off W Dixons Road, 10 kilometres northeast of Edenhope.

urn:contentItem:5SYY-MKC1-JD34-V1DS-00000-00Firefighters join efforts in the United States2018-08-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisFirefighters join efforts in the United StatesAlice Rennison and Anthony Pinda

REGIONAL Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters will assist with the "destructive and devastating" wildfires burning on the United States of America's west coast.

Grampians-based Paul Fernando and Stuart Lardner along with Avoca-based John Moser will join the 188 Australian and New Zealand crew members who are being deployed to the USA.

Fire activity continues across 14 USA states, with about 140 large fires burning across 513,000 hectares of land.

Mr Moser started at FFMVic in 2001 as a project firefighter and now serves as a forest and fire operations officer.

"I'll be working as a sector commander in America - a role that oversees a section of the fire and the resources available to fight it," he said.

"The Americans have assisted us previously, so this is a great opportunity for me to support our overseas friends and colleagues in their time of need.

"I have experience fighting bushfires in many different parts of Victoria including the 2002-03 Big Desert fire, the 2009 Black Saturday fire in Myrtleford, various campaigns in Gippsland and of course bushfires close to home in the Pyrenees.

"I'm eager to apply my skills overseas in a new environment and do what I can to assist. This is my first deployment overseas so I'm also keen to learn from their systems and bring that knowledge back to Victoria."

Mr Fernando and Mr Lardner will join Mr Moser in the United States.

They are from Parks Victoria and their roles in the deployment will be as a divisional commander and sectional commander.

Forest Fire Management Victoria acting assistant chief fire officer Peter Kambouris said Mr Lardner and Mr Fernando were part of 12 staff from Forest Fire Management to be deployed.

"They will assist with the responsibility of the task force," he said.

Mr Kambouris said Australians would also be deployed to Canada.

"Over 170 new wildfires have started in Canada," he said. "They were caused mostly by lightning.

"Six people from the Grampians will be deployed to Canada to assist. They will leave approximately mid-next week.

"We are also mindful of the dry conditions in the Wimmera."

urn:contentItem:5VWP-C5N1-JD34-V1VH-00000-00Clear Lake burned off to combat fairy grass problem2019-04-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisClear Lake burned off to combat fairy grass problemJade Bate

CLEAR Lake's fairy grass problem might subside temporarily after Forest Fire Management Victoria started a control burn of the Clear Lake lake bed.

The burn-off started on April 12 and will end on April 19, with the Country Fire Authority assisting.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Wimmera acting district manager Malcolm Gibson said the objective of the burn was to control the spread of fairy grass throughout Clear Lake.

Parks Victoria describes fairy grass as "a native blown grass which colonises in damp, bare areas and germinates as soon as temperature and moisture levels are suitable".

Related: Clear Lake community's fairy grass concerns continue to grow

Fairy grass grows inside the lake and around the Clear Lake Reserve, and blows out onto neighbouring properties and farms.

Clear Lake residents raised concerns regarding the fairy grass problem in February after a house was destroyed by fire. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

Clear Lake is home to about 40 residents and the town has faced problems with fairy grass since the late 1980s.

Related: Community frustration over fairy grass threat

Residents have repeatedly requested a burn-off of the lake bed in hopes it would subside the fairy grass problem.

In November 2018, Parks Victoria did an assessment of the problem and slashed fairy grass at Clear Lake.

While you're with us, you can now receive updates straight to your inbox twice weekly from the Wimmera Mail-Times. To make sure you're up-to-date with all the news from across the Wimmera, sign up below.

urn:contentItem:5XPJ-44G1-F0J6-J530-00000-00Fire crews to prepare land2019-12-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 16Fire crews to prepare landChris Pedler

Areas around Bendigo, Castlemaine, Echuca, Heathcote and Maryborough will be cleared as suitable weather conditions mean Forest Fire Management Victoria can continue its bushfire fuel reduction program.

Crews will slash, mow and clear more than 1600 hectares of public land to reduce the chance of bushfire.

Prior to summer the authority completed 1050 planned burns, near Bendigo, Fryerstown, Kingower, Heathcote, Rushworth, Laanecoorie and surrounding areas.

Senior fuel management officer Simon Brown said conditions were now suitable to continue fuel reduction by mowing, clearing and slashing.

"FFMVic works closely with the Bureau of Meteorology to assess weather conditions, such as humidity, temperature and wind speed," he said.

"Mowing, slashing and clearing tracks on public land is part of FFMVic's annual fuel reduction program."

Crews are moving through tracks near Bendigo, Castlemaine, Maldon, Echuca, Heathcote, Inglewood, Macedon and Tarnagulla

Avoca, Cohuna, Maryborough, Dunolly, Bealiba, Rushworth and St Arnaud will also be part of the fuel reduction works.

Mr Brown said a three-year joint fuel management plan between Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority determined the actions the organisations undertook.

"In particular, these plans set out where and when activities to reduce bushfire risk will take place, such as planned burning, slashing and mowing, which reduce the leaves, twigs, shrubs and other vegetation that fuel bushfires," he said.

"The joint fuel management plan provides the opportunity communities near public land to provide input around the timing and scheduling of planned burns and other bushfire fuel management activities in their area."

Fuel management includes planned burning, slashing, mowing and clearing vegetation.

"(Fuel management) can assist in reducing the spread and intensity of bushfires, which makes suppression more achievable, and helps keep communities safe and reduce the impact to the environment," Mr Brown said.

"Our Murray Goldfields program is focused on creating a strategic network of boundary fire breaks and internal corridors of fuel reduced areas on public land, so that the potential of large-scale bushfires like the Ash Wednesday fire in 1983 and Black Saturday fire in 2009 is significantly reduced.

"We work closely with communities to manage bushfire fuels and ensure people take appropriate action to prevent fires from occurring and are well prepared for them if they do."

urn:contentItem:43S0-5WP0-0048-T0T7-00000-00<published>2001-08-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:25:45Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Australian General News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Vic: 50 hectare forest fire contained near Toongabbie</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>Scrub<br/><br/>MELBOURNE, Aug 16 AAP - Firefighters are still trying to put out<br/>a forest fire which has destroyed about 50 hectares of bushland<br/>near Toongabbie, in Gippsland, about 150km south-east of Melbourne.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">Country Fire Authority spokesman Peter Philp said a strong<br/>northerly wind meant the fire was flaring as it moved toward<br/>Eaglehawk Creek.</p><p>He said a bulldozer had been used to build a firebreak around<br/>the perimeter of the blaze and that it was listed as contained but<br/>not controlled.<br/></p><p>"It has been described as a slow, and very laborious fire<br/>because it's burning in an old logging coupe," Mr Philp said.<br/></p><p>"There's lots of tree stumps and some of the country is very wet<br/>and inaccessible for fire vehicles to get into."<br/></p><p>No injuries have been reported as a result of the fire.<br/></p><p>Nearer to Melbourne, a fire which burned through 10 hectares of<br/>scrub and grasslands has been brought under control in Yarra<br/>Junction, about 60km east of the city.<br/></p><p>The CFA said the fire started at the back of Reid's Sawmill in<br/>Little Yarra Road about 11.45am (AEST), and had burned through<br/>about 10 hectares.<br/></p><p>Six trucks and 20 firefighters had brought the fire under<br/>control by 1.20pm, he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2001</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:43S0-5WP0-0048-T0T7-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-27</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="207"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2001 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:5RTR-W601-JD34-V552-00000-00Firewood2018-03-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2FirewoodRex Martinich

With the opening of the Autumn Firewood Collection last week on March 1, Forest Fire Management Victoria has reminded firewood collectors to check where designated collection areas are in their local area.

"Firewood is a diminishing resource across Victoria, therefore we cannot guarantee that firewood will be available at all sites for the entire season," acting grampians regional manager of forest and fire operations Taina Scott said.

"In many locations, firewood will be of mixed variety, size and quality, and if recently felled, may also be green; it is recommended that green wood is cut and stored for 12 months before being burnt to maximise heat output,"

"We are aware that many people travel long distances from outside of the local area to secure premium wood supplies, particularly Red Gum.

"There is currently a limited supply of Red Gum across the Grampians region. For this reason, we cannot guarantee that Red Gum will be available from any currently open firewood collection area."

Forest Fire Management Victoria's website also has local weather and forest conditions for collectors to check before venturing out.

You can find out where Firewood Collections Areas are on the Forest Fire Management Victoria website at https://www.ffm.vic.gov.au/firewood/firewood-collection-in-your-region.

"The felling of any trees for firewood by members of the public is strictly prohibited, and we also remind firewood collectors to stay within collection limits," Ms Scott said.

"This includes taking a maximum of two cubic metres per person per day and a maximum of 16 cubic metres per household per financial year to prevent households stockpiling large volumes of firewood and denying others a supply."

If you are aware of the illegal sale of firewood or any unauthorised activity relating to firewood on Victorian public land, we encourage you to report it by calling DELWP on 136 186 or call Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.

"It is illegal to take more than the allowed amount, or to sell firewood that has been collected from public land without an appropriate permit or licence.

"The illegal collection of firewood has the potential to negatively impact on forest environmental values through the removal of habitat.

"We have video surveillance cameras installed in many firewood collections areas, and Forest Fire Management Victoria staff are always out and about, patrolling parks, forests and reserves to ensure people are doing the right thing.

"Under the Forest Act 1958, people who break the rules face an infringement notice of $634, or a maximum penalty of one-year imprisonment or a fine of up to $7,928 or both, if the matter proceeds to court."

urn:contentItem:5XH9-WH31-F0J6-J2TW-00000-00Rules to cut CFA numbers2019-11-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Rules to cut CFA numbersAnthony Bunn

NEW safety requirements mean there will be a drop in volunteer CFA firefighters working in the North East this summer.

District 24 commander Brett Myers said last fire season 895 volunteers responded to incidents, but this summer he estimated it would be "closer to 600".

Increased minimum training levels have prompted the prediction with some volunteers having not completed courses covering entrapment in fire vehicles and on-ground risks such as falling trees.

Despite the reduction, Mr Myers said he did not believe the community would be more at-risk.

"We've still got capability and it's about making sure our people are safe and able to understand how deadly trees are, because they have killed people," he said.

"Even in NSW (recently) we've had trees come down on fire trucks.

"It's real and we've got to make sure our firefighters identify signs of a hazardous tree."

Mr Myers was commenting at a training day for Forest Fire Management Victoria staff at Corryong airport yesterday.

A group of seasonal firefighters honed skills such as loading retardant into a plane and communication.

Forest Fire Upper Murray manager Dave Jenson said his crews were well prepared.

"We're anticipating a long, drawn-out summer and the underlying dryness is the key," Mr Jenson said.

"We're not saying there's going to be more fires, but any fire that does start has the potential to grow rapidly."

Mr Jenson said an increasing worry was unattended campfires with a third of 100 fires in the Upper Murray last season in that category.

"It's knowing when your campfire is out," he said.

"If it's cool to touch, it's cool to leave; just by looking at it you can't see a campfire is all out.

"It just takes a light breeze to blow embers out and start a fire."

A $496 on-the-spot fine can be issued for breaching campfire rules.

As part of the training, pilot Mick Gribble did retardant drops from his plane.

He carries 2800 to 3000 litres of retardant, "a fire truckload", at a time and he and his plane are based at Benambra.

Mr Gribble has been flying his Dromader for five years and been involved in fighting fires for 34 years.

There will be 132 seasonal firefighters across the Hume region this summer.

A group of seasonal firefighters honed skills such as loading retardant into a plane and communication.

Forest Fire Upper Murray manager Dave Jenson said his crews were well prepared.

"We're anticipating a long, drawn-out summer and the underlying dryness is the key," Mr Jenson said.

"We're not saying there's going to be more fires, but any fire that does start has the potential to grow rapidly."

Mr Jenson said an increasing worry was unattended campfires with a third of 100 fires in the Upper Murray last season in that category.

"It's knowing when your campfire is out," he said.

"If it's cool to touch, it's cool to leave; just by looking at it you can't see a campfire is all out.

"It just takes a light breeze to blow embers out and start a fire."

A $496 on-the-spot fine can be issued for breaching campfire rules.

As part of the training, pilot Mick Gribble did retardant drops from his plane.

He carries 2800 to 3000 litres of retardant, "a fire truckload", at a time and he and his plane are based at Benambra.

Mr Gribble has been flying his Dromader for five years and been involved in fighting fires for 34 years.

There will be 132 seasonal firefighters across the Hume region this summer.

urn:contentItem:5XH9-WH31-F0J6-J2RT-00000-00Rules to cut CFA numbers2019-11-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisRules to cut CFA numbersAnthony Bunn

NEW safety requirements mean there will be a drop in volunteer CFA firefighters working in the North East this summer.

District 24 commander Brett Myers said last fire season 895 volunteers responded to incidents, but this summer he estimated it would be "closer to 600".

Increased minimum training levels have prompted the prediction with some volunteers having not completed courses covering entrapment in fire vehicles and on-ground risks such as falling trees.

Despite the reduction, Mr Myers said he did not believe the community would be more at-risk.

"We've still got capability and it's about making sure our people are safe and able to understand how deadly trees are, because they have killed people," he said.

"Even in NSW (recently) we've had trees come down on fire trucks.

"It's real and we've got to make sure our firefighters identify signs of a hazardous tree."

Mr Myers was commenting at a training day for Forest Fire Management Victoria staff at Corryong airport yesterday.

A group of seasonal firefighters honed skills such as loading retardant into a plane and communication.

urn:contentItem:4T2Y-3MB0-TX5N-00C1-00000-00Thousands flee forest fire2008-07-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. 16Thousands flee forest fire

MORE than 2000 tourists were evacuated from hotels on the Greek island of Rhodes as forest fires raged for a fourth day.

Authorities said yesterday the measure was taken as a precaution and affected hotels in the Asklipios area, near the south-east coast of the island.

``Three hotels were evacuated as a precaution, mainly because smoke from the fire had created an unpleasant atmosphere,'' said Haralambos Kokkinos, the South Aegean regional governor. ``The evacuation was orderly and there were no problems. The tourists were taken to the nearby coast and will remain there until the smoke clears. Conditions have already improved and it's likely that the tourists will return to their hotels soon.''

The fire, helped by strong winds, has destroyed thousands of hectares of dense pine forest and came within a few metres of village homes in the centre of the island.

France, Italy and Cyprus have sent firefighting aircraft to help tackle the Rhodes fire.

Also yesterday, a blaze in southern Greece prompted authorities to close a busy highway linking Athens to the western port of Patras for several hours. Rail services in the area were also interrupted.

Three planes and three helicopters were battling a fire at Mandra, west of Athens.

More than 70 people were killed in devastating fires in Greece last year.

urn:contentItem:5VWX-80K1-F0J6-J1CG-00000-00Burn-off combats fairy grass problem2019-04-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Burn-off combats fairy grass problemJade Bate

CLEAR Lake's fairy grass problem might subside temporarily after Forest Fire Management Victoria started a control burn of the Clear Lake lake bed.

The burn-off started on April 12 and will end on April 19, with the Country Fire Authority assisting.

Forest Fire Management Victoria Wimmera acting district manager Malcolm Gibson said the objective of the burn was to control the spread of fairy grass throughout Clear Lake.

Parks Victoria describes fairy grass as "a native blown grass which colonises in damp, bare areas and germinates as soon as temperature and moisture levels are suitable".

Fairy grass grows inside the lake and around the Clear Lake Reserve, and blows out onto neighbouring properties and farms.

Clear Lake residents raised concerns regarding the fairy grass problem in February after a house was destroyed by fire. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

Clear Lake is home to about 40 residents and the town has faced problems with fairy grass since the late 1980s.

Residents have repeatedly requested a burn-off of the lake bed in hopes it would subside the fairy grass problem.

In November 2018, Parks Victoria did an assessment of the problem and slashed fairy grass at Clear Lake.

Natimuk Lake also faces a similar problem with fairy grass. The lake was burned off in 2002 which helped subside the problem, however the grass came back in 2010.

In 2002 a build up of fairy grass caught on fire at Dock Lake Reserve, which threatened people who were at the reserve playing sport. About 225 hectares of land and the Taylors Lake Football Clubrooms were destroyed.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority have reschduled a planned burn around Camp Hill Road at Beaufort.

Firefighters had originally scheduled the planned burn's ignition for October 10 but postponed the operation twice due to unsuitable forecast weather conditions.

"The Beaufort - Camp Hill Road planned burn noted below scheduled for ignition on 20th October has been postponed due to unsuitable weather conditions," a Forest Fire Management Victoria statement said.

"We will be continuing to monitor the weather and fuel conditions and look to deliver this burn within a period of good forecasted conditions from next week Monday October 23 to Thursday October 26."

When the planned burn takes place, smoke might be visible from nearby localities and communities, which could also be affected by smoke from this planned burn.

urn:contentItem:515M-6GW1-JD3N-51F7-00000-00Forest fire threat eases2010-10-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 24Forest fire threat easesKATE DOWLER

FIRE risks near bluegum plantations in southern Victoria and South Australia should ease this summer, according to a forestry industry consultant.

Last summer, many firebreaks were not complete, or were burnt later in the season, following the collapse of bluegum companies Great Southern and Timbercorp.

But forest industry consultant David Geddes said this year fire prevention ``should be on track'' because they were being well managed by new owners Gunns and Australian Bluegum Plantations.

Mr Geddes will speak about fires at the Australian Forest Growers biennial conference in Mount Gambier next week.

Fire-risk management will be a key topic of the four-day conference, which starts on Sunday in the largest plantation region of Australia.

The Green Triangle has more than 20 per cent of the nation's plantations and takes in the southeast of South Australia and southwest Victoria. Mr Geddes said there were five key fire-risk mitigation strategies plantation owners needed to address to protect assets and their communities.

These include upgrading firebreaks, reducing fuel loads, maintaining training and equipment, developing detection systems and fostering relationships with other fire-fighting authorities.

Other speakers include CFA chief executive officer Euan Ferguson and Hancock Victorian Plantations stewardship and risk manager Malcolm Tonkin. Both will speak on fire prevention and lessons from Black Saturday.

HVP lost 16,500ha of plantation and 7800ha of native forest in those fires.

Mr Tonkin said the company had learnt that it needed to put more work into managing pressure on fire fighters.

``What we saw last year was that our fire fighting forces can perform at a high level despite signs of fire-season fatigue, and they continued to provide a strong commitment and focus on fire suppression,'' Mr Tonkin said.

For more information, visit www.afg.asn.au

urn:contentItem:5SYY-MKC1-JD34-V1C4-00000-00Firefighters join efforts in the United States2018-08-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Firefighters join efforts in the United StatesAlice Rennison and Anthony Pinda

REGIONAL Forest Fire Management Victoria firefighters will assist with the "destructive and devastating" wildfires burning on the United States of America's west coast.

Grampians-based Paul Fernando and Stuart Lardner along with Avoca-based John Moser will join the 188 Australian and New Zealand crew members who are being deployed to the USA.

Fire activity continues across 14 USA states, with about 140 large fires burning across 513,000 hectares of land.

Mr Moser started at FFMVic in 2001 as a project firefighter and now serves as a forest and fire operations officer.

"I'll be working as a sector commander in America - a role that oversees a section of the fire and the resources available to fight it," he said.

"The Americans have assisted us previously, so this is a great opportunity for me to support our overseas friends and colleagues in their time of need.

"I have experience fighting bushfires in many different parts of Victoria including the 2002-03 Big Desert fire, the 2009 Black Saturday fire in Myrtleford, various campaigns in Gippsland and of course bushfires close to home in the Pyrenees.

"I'm eager to apply my skills overseas in a new environment and do what I can to assist. This is my first deployment overseas so I'm also keen to learn from their systems and bring that knowledge back to Victoria."

Mr Fernando and Mr Lardner will join Mr Moser in the United States.

They are from Parks Victoria and their roles in the deployment will be as a divisional commander and sectional commander.

Forest Fire Management Victoria acting assistant chief fire officer Peter Kambouris said Mr Lardner and Mr Fernando were part of 12 staff from Forest Fire Management to be deployed.

"They will assist with the responsibility of the task force," he said.

Mr Kambouris said Australians would also be deployed to Canada.

"Over 170 new wildfires have started in Canada," he said. "They were caused mostly by lightning.

"Six people from the Grampians will be deployed to Canada to assist. They will leave approximately mid-next week.

"We are also mindful of the dry conditions in the Wimmera."

urn:contentItem:55N2-0421-F0NH-V2BC-00000-00Family escapes forest fire2012-05-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisNEWS - GENERALFamily escapes forest fireCeleste Lustosa

Paul Kretschmer and his family put their bushfire plan to the test last week when a burn-off got out of control and devastated 800 hectares of the Wirrabara Forest.

Mr Krestschmer has lived in the region since 1998 and said he had never experienced such a frightening situation.

"This was the worst fire I have ever seen," he said."We live in a place classified as high fire area, so we always though one day we would have an incident. There was a big fire here in 2001 but this one was worse."

Five proprieties, including the one where Mr Krestschmer lives with his wife Denise and children Raymond, 15 and Renae 12, were in a risky spot during the fire.

"These were very anxious days for us. The Country Fire Service came to our house and said the fire was uncontained and coming towards us and we had to either leave or be prepared to put our bushfire plan to the test," he said.

"We made the decision as a family that we would stay, so we filled buckets with water, shifted the cattle to safety and were alert day and night."

But things got worst and, when two CFS trucks stopped at their driveway, Mr Kretschmer knew they were not bringing good news.

"At that stage, emergency services volunteers were focusing on our assets' protection," he said.

"It was very alarming to see that red glow so close to us. The fire burnt up to across the road from us.

"Situations like this make you think of your bushfire plan, but until you put it to the test, you won't know how it would go.

"Everyone should be prepared for when it happens. Although the fire did not reach us, it showed our weakness."

More than 100 volunteers from around the region worked around the clock to ensure people's safety.

"We are grateful for the effort that the CFS and SES put into this operation to protect us and our proprieties," he said.

"We were also given good warning and kept informed on what was happening which made a big different. Thank you!"

urn:contentItem:5TJT-5CF1-F0J6-J47P-00000-00Fuel reduction burns planned for Maiden Gully and Sailors Gully2018-10-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisFuel reduction burns planned for Maiden Gully and Sailors Gully

Planned fuel-reduction burns will be held in the Maiden Gully and Sailors Gully areas on Thursday, Forest Fire Management Victoria said.

The burn in the are of Edwards Rd, Maiden Gully will cover 116 hectares, 5.5 kilometres west of Bendigo.

A 189 hectares fuel-reduction burn will be carried out in the are of Sydney Flat, Sailors Gully, 7.5 kilometres north west of Bendigo

Both controlled burns will be in the Bendigo Regional Park, with smoke likely to be visible from Bendigo, Maiden Gully, Eaglehawk, Sailors Gully and Kangaroo Flat.

Forest Fire Management said that the burns should be completed between 9am and 8pm on October 25.

Read more

If you are experiencing any symptoms that may be due to smoke exposure, the Department of Health and Human Services advises that you should seek medical advice or call nurse on1300 606 024. It is also advised that window and doors are closed to prevent smoke from entering.

Road travel may be hazardous due to low visibility associated with smoke in these areas.

Access to walking tracks, car parks, camping grounds and picnic sites in areas close to or in burn areas may be restricted

urn:contentItem:5TFT-K971-JD34-V55R-00000-00Planned burns to begin in central Victoria2018-10-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Planned burns to begin in central VictoriaNatalie Croxon

Five planned burns are due to take place in central Victoria from Thursday, as Forest Fire Management Victoria takes advantage of milder conditions.

The first burn will be conducted in the Redcastle Greytown State Forest near Rushworth.

Three burns will take place around Maryborough: the first on Thursday at Mosquito Track, 4.5 kilometres south-east of Maryborough, the second on Friday at Station Lane, 9.7 kilometres south-west of the town, and another 2.5 kilometres south-west at Derby Road on Saturday.

If conditions are suitable on Friday, FFM Victoria will carry out a burn at Inglewood Reservoir.

Related: Fire conditions equal to some of Victoria's worst seasons

"The aim of conducting the burns is to reduce the overall fuel hazard within the burn area and in turn, provide added protection from bushfire to neighbouring communities," FFM Victoria's district manager Paul Bates said.

"These burns are part of an integrated plan to reduce bushfire risk to people, property and highly valued assets.

"They aim to reduce the speed and intensity of future bushfires."

Related: Forest Fire Management Victoria warns of burn-off safety

Anyone concerned about the presence of smoke should call VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226, rather than triple zero.

People experiencing symptoms because of smoke exposure should seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 60 60 24.

urn:contentItem:5X2R-XGG1-F0JP-W02T-00000-00Firefighters fly north to join Queensland battle2019-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15Firefighters fly north to join Queensland battleOlivia Reed

QUEENSCLIFF and Anglesea Forest Fire Management staff have been deployed to Queensland to provide emergency management support during the bushfires raging across the state.

Specialist personnel from Forest Fire Management Victoria's Colac, Anglesea and Queenscliff offices are among a multi-agency contingent -requested by the Queensland Government.

Fires continue to rage across the state, but in the past few days hundreds of people who were forced to flee their homes across southern and southeast Queensland have -finally been allowed to -return.

Residents living in Peregian Beach on the Sunshine Coast were some of the most severely affected, with police alleging the blaze that tore through the area was deliberately lit by a teenage boy and girl.

Anglesea's Ellen Harper will use her skills as a logistics officer to co-ordinate meals, accommodation and equipment.

Ms Harper has led and -supported logistics during a number of major fires including last year's bushfires in Queensland, the Wye River bushfires and the Black Saturday bushfires.

Andrew McKinnon of Queenscliff will take on the role of a situation officer, tasked with analysing the weather, fire movement and other data to produce reports on the fire situation.

Mr McKinnon has experience assisting with a range of emergencies at a local and state level.

Meanwhile, Colac's Sandra Robinson will assist with her aircraft officer skills, and will oversee the management of an air base and manage a large and varied fleet of aircraft -involved in the firefight.

Ms Robinson has more than 20 years' experience in aircraft management and played a key role in the aircraft team during the Wye River bushfires.

The trio flew out of Melbourne Airport last Wednesday and will be based in Cairns.

FFMVic Otway district manager David Roberts said he was confident the personnel would provide valuable skills and support.

"These are some of our reg-ion's most experienced emergency management personnel, with years of experience in helping respond to fires and other emergencies," Mr Roberts said.

"We wish them all the best for this challenging deployment and look forward to learning from their experiences after they return home."FFMVic said it had a strong and ongoing relationship with Queensland, which allowed for the exchange of personnel, knowledge, skills, equipment, technology and mutual support in the event of an -emergency.

urn:contentItem:5TFT-K971-JD34-V54K-00000-00Planned burns to begin in central Victoria2018-10-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisPlanned burns to begin in central VictoriaNatalie Croxon

Five planned burns are due to take place in central Victoria from Thursday, as Forest Fire Management Victoria takes advantage of milder conditions.

The first burn will be conducted in the Redcastle Greytown State Forest near Rushworth.

Three burns will take place around Maryborough: the first on Thursday at Mosquito Track, 4.5 kilometres south-east of Maryborough, the second on Friday at Station Lane, 9.7 kilometres south-west of the town, and another 2.5 kilometres south-west at Derby Road on Saturday.

If conditions are suitable on Friday, FFM Victoria will carry out a burn at Inglewood Reservoir.

Related: Fire conditions equal to some of Victoria's worst seasons

"The aim of conducting the burns is to reduce the overall fuel hazard within the burn area and in turn, provide added protection from bushfire to neighbouring communities," FFM Victoria's district manager Paul Bates said.

"These burns are part of an integrated plan to reduce bushfire risk to people, property and highly valued assets.

"They aim to reduce the speed and intensity of future bushfires."

Related: Forest Fire Management Victoria warns of burn-off safety

Anyone concerned about the presence of smoke should call VicEmergency Hotline on 1800 226 226, rather than triple zero.

People experiencing symptoms because of smoke exposure should seek medical advice or call NURSE-ON-CALL on 1300 60 60 24.

urn:contentItem:5V9T-MTH1-JCM0-61J0-00000-00Cultural burning to return to Victoria after 170 years in the hope of revitalising the land2019-01-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:25:45ZLexisNexisCultural burning to return to Victoria after 170 years in the hope of revitalising the landSean Wales

Indigenous cultural burning has been reintroduced in central Victoria for the first time in almost 200 years.

Forest Fire Management Victoria and Dja Dja Wurrung Clans Aboriginal Corporation (DDWCAC) will bring back the practice after collaborating with traditional owners in the United States and Canada.

DDWCAC director Trent Nelson said bringing back Indigenous cultural burnings will not only help reconnect Indigenous people to their history, but also assist in maintaining the land for future generations.

"For Dja Dja Wurrung people it's about having our right to bring back our practices that our ancestors did many years ago," he said.

Mr Nelson recently returned from a trip to the US and Canada where he found similarities in how the two native cultures deal with land management.

"Looking at traditional owners in America [compared] with here in Victoria there are a lot of similarities with our cultural values and aspirations to using cultural burnings and fire as a land management tool," Mr Nelson said.

"I found that our fire and land management is actually well advanced compared to America when it comes to involving traditional owners."

In 2017, Bega Local Aboriginal Land Council in New South Walesbegan a cultural burning program as part of its management strategy for their landholdings.

Mr Nelson, a Dja Dja Wurrung and Yorta Yorta man, is working closely with Forest Fire Management Victoria to understand how Victoria's Indigenous burnings can complement modern fire and land management.

"Dja Dja Wurrung, working with Forest Fire Management Victoria, is unique because a lot of cultural burns have been done on private blocks of land," he said.

"What we are doing is on public land so it's a different process. We are embedding it into the same process as doing planned burns across the state.

"It has been more than 170 years since burnings were done on Dja Dja Wurrung country.

"We want to try and utilise cultural burnings to be able to manage public landscapes for future generations."

Cultural shift to enable future burnings

Scott Falconer, who accompanied Mr Nelson on the overseas trip, is the assistant chief fire officer with Forest Fire Management Victoria, and said 27 cultural burns are scheduled for the next two years, something he said was a huge achievement.

Mr Falconer said creating positions for Indigenous people within organisations such as his was the way forward in helping to maintain public land.

"One of the roles of non-Aboriginal people is to enable and build capability, and then just get out of the way," he said.

"That's a cultural change for our organisation so we are working on that as well. There's a lot of support by government and agencies. Traditional owners are driving this and we need to listen to them.

"I think all Australians can benefit greatly from understanding our history better and doing things like this to enable self-determination for Indigenous people."

Mr Nelson said the goal for DDWCAC was to build trust with government agencies by having Indigenous people conducting cultural burns on Dja Dja Wurrung country in central Victoria across the next two years.

"It's always good to have learnings, but for us it's about the practical outcomes and having our people out there burning," he said.

"Every time we burn we learn something new and that's what it's about - building the department's confidence in us so we can work together in the future."

Cultural burnings connect people to country

Alongside helping to maintain public land, Mr Nelson said cultural burnings help re-connect Indigenous people with their history.

"There are a lot of different aspirations and objectives for why we do cultural burnings," he said.

"We want to use fire as a technique and a tool to heal country but also in healing our people, and involving families, elders and young ones through traditional burning."

Mr Falconer said engaging with Indigenous practices can be mutually beneficial.

"It's really about how do we listen to what Aboriginal people know and what they can add in Victoria, where we are one of the most fire prone areas in the world," he said.

"We have had so many learnings, including how to engage with traditional owners from a western perspective. We really want this to be an ongoing learning."
